comments.body: Since leading/trailing typically refers to left/right widgets maybe a better name is top/bottom? Not sold on this though so whatever you feel is best
I will leave it as is since that what was in the design doc which was reviewed.
Why is this a restriction? Could the `labelType` just be ignored if extended is true instead?
Yeah it could be ignored but I think its better to disallow it (its a rare case that the labelType will be dynamic anyway)
I think this should specify that this is the width when the rail is extended, since the user could simply not bother with the non-extended rail and so the animation isn't even used.
Done

Does this allow the rail to read the semantics out similar to bottom navigation?

"Selected, calendar, tab 1 of 3"
"Comments, tab 2 of 3"
Yes I pulled it from there, it adds an additional label to the string
Should the splash/hover color be based on the icon/text colors if those are provided?
I think they could, but then again it might cause confusion whether it comes from the icon or the label.
gotcha, fine as-is then.

comments.body: New line above here
Done

Explain that the appearance of all of the Rails in an application can be specified with NavigationRailTheme etc. I'm hoping that we can say that if a NavigationRailTheme's property is null then the default value is base on the overall [Theme]'s textTheme and colorScheme.
NICE
Could put a "main content" comment here to tie the example back to the explanatory text

This property, like all of the properties whose default values are based on the theme system, should explain the default value. In this case it's navigationRailTheme.backgroundColor, and if that's null then theme.colorScheme.surface.
This would be a good place to explain what "extended state" means
The leading widget is placed at the top of the rail. It's location is not affected by [groupAlignment] (right?)
Correct, updated
Same comment as for leading.
Updated to reflect how trailing works (its always right at the end of the destinations)
Restate the length constraint here.

Same comment as for preferredWidth. I think this should just be "wide enough". Developers may want to insert padding for this case and the "preferred one", i.e.  contentPadding instead of preferredWidth and extendedContentPadding instead of extendedWidth.

Updated to minExtendedWidth to match minWidth.

I think this is consistent with the way minWidth works, which would be trickier to work with a user defined padding because it has to work with only icons, and icons with labels.
Sounds good
This really needs an example
Done
Glad to see this! The sample doesn't appear to have been updated per the latest API changes, like currentIndex => selectedIndex
I have opened an issue in samples to update once this lands (it is using an earlier copy of this component): https://github.com/flutter/samples/issues/383

For the sake of consistency, and to make it possible to theme these values later, we could make the default values of minWidth and minExtendedWidth null, and create final vars here that use the _foo defaults.
This would be a good place to mention [minExtendedWidth].
Do we really need this? Why isn't this just the last destination? Even if developers are only going to include it when specifying extended=true,  it's easy enough to do so by hand.

I think it needs to be a slot for an extra widget, because destinations are not configured by passing in a widget or list of widgets, but rather a data model that creates a widget. Leaving it open like this also makes it easy to place any horizontal dividers.
This doesn't really explain what the property means.
Added a defining 1st sentence

I think we can make this simpler. The IconTheme that wraps each destination could be
```dart
final IconThemeData defaultSelectedIconTheme = navigationRailTheme.selectedIconTheme;
final IconThemeData selectedIconTheme = IconThemeData(
  size: defaultSelectedIconTheme?.size ?? _defaultSelectedIconSize,
  color: defaultSelectedIconTheme?.color ?? _defaultSelectedIconColor,
  opacity: defaultSelectedIconTheme?.opacity ?? _defaultSelectedIconOpacity,
);
```

In other words it would only depend on the navigation rail's theme for default overrides.

Likewise for the selectedIconTheme.
Done, but with `ThemeData defaultSelectedIconTheme = widget.selectedIconTheme ?? navigationRailTheme.selectedIconTheme;` so the component defined icon theme is used
Yes!
Is this going to produce an intuitive results when the icon isn't an Icon widget (whose size we're defining)?  Maybe the themedIcon should be centered within a minWidthXminWidth box?
Need a reply for this?
Done

comments.body: "Not selected"? Should this be named selectedIcon?
Yes, I originally chose activeIcon to stay consistent with the BottomNavigationBar, but it probably makes more sense to stay consistent within the NavigationRail
